dc:source.dc:abstract: To identify the gene underlying Fanconi anemia (FA) complementation group I we studied informative FA-I families by a genome-wide linkage analysis, which resulted in 4 candidate regions together encompassing 351 genes. Candidates were selected via bioinformatics and data mining on the basis of their resemblance to other FA genes/proteins acting in the FA pathway, such as: degree of evolutionary conservation, presence of nuclear localization signals and pattern of tissue-dependent expression. We found a candidate, KIAA1794 on chromosome 15q25-26, to be mutated in 8 affected individuals previously assigned to complementation group I. Western blots of endogenous FANCI indicated that functionally active KIAA1794 protein is lacking in FA-I individuals. Knock-down of KIAA1794 expression by siRNA in HeLa cells caused excessive chromosomal breakage induced by mitomycin C, a hallmark of FA cells. Furthermore, phenotypic reversion of a patient-derived cell line was associated with a secondary genetic alteration at the KIAA1794 locus. These data add up to two conclusions. First, KIAA1794 is a FA gene. Second, this gene is identical to FANCI, since the patient cell lines found mutated in this study included the reference cell line for group I, EUFA592.
dc:source.dc:creator: Dorsman JC
dc:source.dc:title: Identification of the Fanconi anemia complementation group I gene, FANCI.

evidence.dc:description: This male lacks complementation after hybridization with FA-I lymphoblasts; One variant is missense and the other results in an in-frame deletion of exon 27, encoding one of the SQE motifs. Western blot showed complete absence of KIAA1794/FANCI protein.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: multiple congenital malformations including thumb, kidney, heart, brain.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Activation of the Fanconi anemia (FA) DNA damage-response pathway results in the monoubiquitination of FANCD2, which is regulated by the nuclear FA core ubiquitin ligase complex. A FANCD2 protein sequence-based homology search facilitated the discovery of FANCI, a second monoubiquitinated component of the FA pathway. Biallelic mutations in the gene coding for this protein were found in cells from four FA patients, including an FA-I reference cell line.
dc:source.dc:creator: Sims AE
dc:source.dc:title: FANCI is a second monoubiquitinated member of the Fanconi anemia pathway.

evidence.rdfs:label: IFAR663

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Fanconi facies, right ear canal atresia, septo‐optic dysplasia, small pituitary, café au lait macules, pale optic disk, hypoplastic optic nerves, mild GH deficiency, Bilateral absent thumbs, short right radius, fusion of C5‐C6 vertebral bodies, small kidneys

dc:source.dc:abstract: Fanconi anemia (FA) is an inherited bone marrow failure syndrome caused by mutations in DNA repair genes; some of these patients may have features of the VACTERL association. Autosomal recessive mutations in FANCI are a rare cause of FA. We identified FANCI mutations by next generation sequencing in three patients in our FA cohort among several whose mutated gene was unknown. Four of the six mutations are novel and all mutations are likely deleterious to protein function. There are now 16 reported cases of FA due to FANCI of whom 7 have at least 3 features of the VACTERL association (44%). This suggests that the VACTERL association in patients with FA may be seen in patients with FANCI mutations more often than previously recognized.
dc:source.dc:creator: Savage SA
dc:source.dc:title: Novel FANCI mutations in Fanconi anemia with VACTERL association.

evidence.rdfs:label: NCI-82-1

evidence.dc:description: This girl was born to non‐consanguineous parents of Northern European and American Indian ancestry.  WES was performed on her using AR inheritance model; the unaffected sibling and one parent were both carriers of only the insertion, the other parent was not available. but long range sequencing analysis confirmed these mutations affected separate alleles.
This female was born to an Indian consanguineous parents. This homozygous variant showed week FANCI/KIAA1794 protein by western blot.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Thumb/radius aplasia, kidney and cardiac anomalies.
evidence.rdfs:label: EUFA961

evidence.dc:description: This male was born to a non-consanguineous parents. Western blot showed absent of FANCI (KIAA1794 protein).

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Multiple congenital malformations including thumb, kidney, hearing loss, BM failure at age 6 years.
evidence.rdfs:label: F010095

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Thumb radius aplasia, kidney and cardiac anomalies
evidence.rdfs:label: EUFA592

evidence.dc:description: This female was born to a consanguineous Turkey family. This variant is at the first codon for methionine. Western blot showed absence of full lenght protein from lymphoblasts from this individual. Cell line from this individual showed weak but specific interaction of FANCD2 and FANCI by coinmmunoprecipitation.

The maternal allele contained a premature stop (c.3853C>T) in exon 37, whereas the paternal
allele carried a mutation (c.3350-88A>G) in intron 31 resulting in abnormal splicing. Western blot showed absent FANCI protein.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Short left first metacarpal, chiari malformation, small anterior pituitary gland with poorly visible stalk, mild bilateral conductive hearing loss, hypoplastic thumbs, short neck with narrow C5 vertebra, VSD, ASD, PDA, grade 3 vesicoureteral reflux requiring ureter re‐implantation.
evidence.rdfs:label: NCI-309-1

evidence.dc:description: This female was born to non‐consanguineous parents of Asian, Hispanic, European, and Native American ancestry. Diagnosis of FA at birth.  One parent carried the p.Ser347Pro mutation whereas the other parent carried the p.Gly401Glufs*3 mutation.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Premature with intrauterine growth retardation, narrow ear canals, abnormal middle ear bones,  abnormal corpus callosum, café au lait macules, abnormal cervical vertebra, dangling left thumb, PFO.
evidence.rdfs:label: NCI-251-1

evidence.dc:description: This female was born to to non‐consanguineous parents of European and Hispanic ancestry. WES on this individual. Targeted sequencing revealed that one parent carried the Cys1014Tyr mutation and the other carried the Tyr487X mutation.

evidence.detectionMethod: Direct genomic and cDNA sequencing was performed for FANCA/B/C/D2/E/F/G/J according to standard protocols, the sequence KIAA1794 exons.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Thumb and radial aplasia, anemia at 1 year of age.
evidence.rdfs:label: F010191

evidence.dc:description: These two nonsense variants are located in exon 19 and 37, respectively. The R1299X mutation produce a truncated shorter form of the FANCI protein and the other R614X does not produce protein due to NMD or protein instability.

Western blot showing absence of full-length KIAA1794 protein in extracts from lymphoblasts derived from FA-I individuals, except for individual BD952 carrying a missense mutation. HSC93, wild type lymphoblasts.
evidence.rdfs:label: Western blot

evidence.dc:description: All  extracts from 4 patient derived lymphoblasts showed absence of full length KIAA1794/FANCI protein. One (BD952)  carrying missense variants showed weak protein expression.
FANCD2 monoubiquitination was absence in HeLa cells transfected with FANCI/KIAA1794 specific siRNA.
evidence.rdfs:label: Western blot for FANCD2 monoubiquitination

evidence.dc:description: HeLa cell with FANCI specific siRNA transfection (FANCI knockdown) showed absence of FANCD2 monoubiquitination.

HeLa cell transfected with FANCI specific siRNA transfection showed hypersensitive to mitomycin C. FA-like cellular phenotype induced in HeLa cells upon siRNA-mediated knock-down of KIAA1794/FANCI expression.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mitomycin chromosome breakage

evidence.dc:description: HeLa cell with FANCI specific siRNA transfection (FANCI knockdown) showed MMC hypersensitivity.
Absence of monoubiquitination of FANCD2 in the lymphobablst from EUFA816.
evidence.rdfs:label: Western blot for monoubiquitination of FANCD2

evidence.dc:description: monubiquitination of FANCD2 is absent in lymphoblasts from this individual,  and this phenotype was reversed by an additional mutation in intron 31 (c.3349+97T>G) which reduce the aberrant splicing.
MMC induced chromosome breakage in lymphoblasts from EUFA816.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mitomycin C induced chromosome breakage

evidence.dc:description: MMC induced chromosome breakage in lymphoblast cells, and this phenotype was reversed by an additional mutation in intron 31 (c.3349+97T>G) which reduce the aberrant splicing.

Lower peripheral blood platelet counts in in both single mutant mice and double mutant mice compared to the wild-type mice. None marrow hematopoietic progenitors from all mutant mice were hypersensitive to mitomycin C.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Fanconi Anemia (FA) clinical phenotypes are heterogenous and rely on a mutation in one of the 22 FANC genes (FANCA-W) involved in a common interstrand DNA crosslink-repair pathway. A critical step in the activation of FA pathway is the monoubiquitination of FANCD2 and its binding partner FANCI. To better address the clinical phenotype associated with FANCI and the epistatic relationship with FANCD2, we created the first conditional inactivation model for FANCI in mouse. Fanci -/- mice displayed typical FA features such as delayed development in utero, microphtalmia, cellular sensitivity to mitomycin C, occasional limb abnormalities and hematological deficiencies. Interestingly, the deletion of Fanci leads to a strong meiotic phenotype and severe hypogonadism. FANCI was localized in spermatocytes and spermatids and in the nucleus of oocytes. Both FANCI and FANCD2 proteins co-localized with RPA along meiotic chromosomes, albeit at different levels. Consistent with a role in meiotic recombination, FANCI interacted with RAD51 and stimulated D-loop formation, unlike FANCD2. The double knockout Fanci-/- Fancd2-/- also showed epistatic relationship for hematological defects while being not epistatic with respect to generating viable mice in crosses of double heterozygotes. Collectively, this study highlights common and distinct functions of FANCI and FANCD2 during mouse development, meiotic recombination and hematopoiesis.
dc:source.dc:creator: Dubois EL
dc:source.dc:title: A Fanci knockout mouse model reveals common and distinct functions for FANCI and FANCD2.

evidence.rdfs:label: Bone marrow hematopoiesis assays

evidence.dc:description: Fanci knockout mice displayed typical FA features such as delayed development in utero, microphtalmia, cellular sensitivity to mitomycin C, occasional limb abnormalities and hematological deficiencies. Interestingly, the deletion of Fanci leads to a strong meiotic phenotype and severe hypogonadism.  Embryonic lethality of Fanci-/- in mice is also observed.

dc:description: Fanconi anemia (FA) is a disease of DNA repair characterized by bone marrow failure, increased risk for malignancy, short stature, abnormal skin pigmentation, skeletal malformations of the upper and lower limbs, microcephaly, and ophthalmic and genitourinary tract anomalies (PMID: 21701511;29051281). The cellular hallmark of FA is hypersensitivity to DNA crosslinking agents such as diepoxybutane (DEB) and mitomycin C (MMC), and high frequency of chromosomal aberrations. FANCD2 and FANCI form a protein complex (ID complex), their monoubiquitination is codependent and requires the FA core complex. FANCI was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Fanconi anemia complementation group I in 2007 [Dorsman JC et al., PMID: 17452773]. The genetic evidence provided here stems from three Fanconi anemia patient cohorts [PMID: 26590883, 17460694 and 17452773]. These patients are either homozygous or compound heterozygous for pathogenetic FANCI variants. Lymphoblasts from these patients showed absence or weak expression of FANCI protein, absence of FANCD2 monoubiquitination and hypersensitivity to mitomycin (MMC) exposure [PMID: 17452773]. Fanci mouse models (Fanci +/- and Fanci -/-) showed FA features such as delayed development in utero, microphthalmia, cellular sensitivity to mitomycin C, occasional limb abnormalities and hematological deficiencies. Embryonic lethality in Fanci -/- mice was observed (PMID: 31219578). Functional studies include extensive evidence of absent FANCD2 monoubiquitination and MMC hypersensitivity from FA patients’ lymphoblasts and from HeLa with FANCI specific siRNA transfection [PMID: 17460694]. In summary, FANCI is definitively associated with FA complementation group I. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time.
